revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=November 2014}} [[File:Bihari Sándor Önarckép.jpg|thumb|200px|Self-portrait (1880s?)]] '''Sándor Bihari''' (19 May 1855, [[Rézbánya]] - 28 March 1906, [[Budapest]]) was a [[Jewish]] Hungarian [[Genre art|genre]] painter. == Life == Born to a [[Jewish]] family, Sándor spent his childhood in [[Nagyvárad]]. Originally, he worked with his father as a decorative painter. In 1874, he moved to Budapest, where he did [[photo manipulation|retouching]] at a photography studio while attending a drawing school operated by [[Bertalan Székely]].[http://www.mke.hu/lyka/05/353-365-bihari.htm Béla Fónagy: Bihari Sándor] @ Művészet (from 1906) Two years later, he used his meager resources on a move to Vienna, where he hoped to enroll in the [[Academy of Fine Arts Vienna|Academy of Fine Arts]]. At first he had to find work as a retoucher again and might have remained in that position, had he not received a gift of 600 [[Forint]]s from Székely, which enabled him to quit his job and enter the Academy. He returned to his hometown, where he spent three years struggling as a portrait painter until a benefactor who liked his work provided the means for him to study in Paris. He travelled there in 1883, where he studied at the [[Académie Julian]] with [[Jean-Paul Laurens]] and improved his technique by copying the [[Old Masters]] at the [[Louvre]]. While there, he became acquainted with [[plein-air]] painting and [[Impressionism (art)|Impressionism]], which had a decisive influence on his style. Upon returning to Hungary, he settled in [[Szolnok]], a popular gathering place for painters, and would later become one of the founders of an art colony there. He continued to travel, making lengthy visits to Italy especially, until his health began to fail in 1893. During his final years, he lived in Budapest but continued to spend his summers in Szolnok. In 1896, he was awarded the [[Order of Franz Joseph]]. ==Selected paintings== File:Sonntagnachmittag Sandor Bihari.jpg|Sunday Afternoon (1893) File:Bihari Boating on the River Zagyva 1886.jpg|Boating on the [[Zagyva River]] (1886) File:Bihari Sándor Bíró előtt.jpg|Before the Judge (1886),
his most familiar painting. File:Bihari, Sandor - On the Porch (ca 1900).jpg|On the Porch (c.1900) ==References== {{reflist}} == External links == {{commons category|Sándor Bihari}} * [http://www.artnet.com/artists/sandor-alexander-bihari/past-auction-results ArtNet: More works by Bihari] * [http://mek.oszk.hu/04000/04093/html/0130.html Biography] @ the Magyar Elektronikus Könyvtár. * [https://books.google.com/books?id=ottDAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA51 ''A Modell''], by Sándor Bihari @ Google Books {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bihari, Sandor}} [[Category:1855 births]] [[Category:1906 deaths]] [[Category:People from Nucet]] [[Category:Hungarian Jews]] [[Category:Jewish artists]] [[Category:Genre painters]] [[Category:19th-century Hungarian painters]]

page.title: The Bridge Stage of the Arts

revision.text:
{{Infobox organization |name = The Bridge Stage of the Arts, Inc. |bgcolor = |fgcolor = |image = |image_border = |size = |alt = |caption = |map = |msize = |malt = |mcaption = |abbreviation = |motto = |formation = 1980 |extinction = |type = Intercultural, inter-disciplinary theater production company |status = not-for-profit organization (501(c)(3)) |purpose = To further collaborative creation of new theatrical hybrids by spanning different disciplines, cultures and generations; and to provide educational programs. |headquarters = [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]] |location = New York City, New York |region_served = International |membership = |language = English |leader_title = Founder and Artistic Director |leader_name = Avra Petrides (November 21, 1938- )<ref>New York City Birth and Death Records</ref> |main_organ = |parent_organization = |affiliations = |num_staff = |num_volunteers = |budget = |website = |remarks = }} '''The Bridge Stage of the Arts, Inc.''' ('''The Bridge''') is an [[United States|American]] theater company based in [[New York City]]. It was incorporated by its Artistic Director, Avra Petrides, in 1980;<ref name="Incorporation 1980">Certificate of Incorporation, is dated April 21, 1980, and signed by the Secretary of State, Basil Paterson</ref> and has produced American/International music- theater festivals in the [[South of France]] ([[Languedoc-Roussillon]] region) with American musical-theater artists such as [[Alan Jay Lerner]], lyricist and librettist of ''[[My Fair Lady]]'', and [[Betty Comden]] and [[Adolph Green]] screenwriters and lyricists of ''[[Singin' In The Rain]].''<ref name="Int Herald Trib 1984 Jul 25" /><ref>La Depeche, July 6, 1982</ref> These artists performed and also gave master classes on musical theater to lyricists, librettists, playwrights, composers, directors, and performers from all over the world. In [[Lower Manhattan]] The Bridge has presented ''Performance-Forums'' in which theater artists collaborate on productions with astrophysicists, philosophers, architects and others working in a variety of disciplines.<ref name="Time Out 1996 Mar 27" /><ref name="World Notes 1996 Sum" /> Also, in [[Lower Manhattan]], The Bridge produced ''Hart & Hammerstein Centennial Plus One'' which re-introduced ''[[Castle Clinton]]'' as a noteworthy performance space.<ref name="NYTs 1996 Jun 2" /><ref name="Courier Lifestyles 1996 Jun 3" />
==Purpose== The purpose of The Bridge is to further collaborative creation of new theatrical hybrids by spanning different disciplines, cultures and generations; and to provide educational programs in the performing and visual arts.
==Notable productions== In the [[South of France]], The Bridge presented ''[[Alan Jay Lerner]] and [[Liz Robertson]] In Concert'', ''[[Honi Coles]] and The Copasetics In Concert'', and ''[[Betty Comden]] and [[Adolph Green]] In Concert''.<ref name="Int Herald Trib 1984 Jul 25" /><ref>"La Depeche 1982 July 6"</ref> In [[Lower Manhattan]], The Bridge has produced its ''Performance-Forums'' with astrophysicist, [[Neil deGrasse Tyson]], theater director, [[Tom O'Horgan]] and others.<ref name="Time Out 1996 Mar 27" /><ref name="World Notes 1996 Sum" /> And in June 2001, it presented ''Hart & Hammerstein Centennial Plus One'' at [[Castle Clinton]], near the [[World Trade Center (1973–2001)|World Trade Center]] in [[Lower Manhattan]].<ref name="Backstage 2001 Feb 21" /> The production was the first of a summer concert series, and marked the first time in 146 years that [[Castle Clinton]] had been used as a theater. [[Castle Clinton]], a {{age|1811|01|01}}-year-old circular stone garrison built in 1811 to protect New York from the warring British, has served as an indoor garden, an opera house, an aquarium, an immigrant landing depot, and the setting in which the "[[Swedish Nightingale]]" [[Jenny Lind]] made her 1850 American debut, courtesy of [[P.T. Barnum]]; also, in recent years, as a ticket booth for ferries to the [[Statue of Liberty]].<ref name="NYTs 1996 Jun 2" /><ref name="Courier Lifestyles 1996 Jun 3" />
==Founder and artistic director== Avra Petrides, a native New Yorker, is the daughter of pioneering woman orchestral conductor, [[Frédérique Petrides]], and journalist, Peter Petrides, who, for many years was managing editor of the New York City-based, Greek-American newspaper, The National Herald (not to be confused with the newspaper of the same name that was established in 1997).<ref name="Groh 1991" />
Before becoming Artistic Director of The Bridge, her many appearances as an actress included Honey, the young wife, in the original Broadway production of [[Edward Albee]]'s ''[[Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?]]'' (in the matinee company, opposite [[Kate Reid]] and [[Shepperd Strudwick]]);<ref name="NY Herald Trib 1962 Oct 11" /> starring as Leah with [[Joseph Wiseman]] and [[Luther Adler]] in the CBC ([[Canadian Broadcasting Company]]) television adaptation of [[Ansky]]'s ''[[The Dybbuk]]'';<ref>[http://www.tvarchive.ca/database/16976/festival/episode_guide/ Canadian Film Festival May 1, 1961]</ref> playing [[Bette Davis]] in Adrienne Kennedy's ''A Movie Star Has To Star in Black and White'', directed by [[Joseph Chaikin]] at [[Joseph Papp]]'s [[Public Theater]];<ref>"Gavella Orchestrates a Sigh, With the Under-Title A Movie Star Has to Star in Black and White" (review), by Arthur Sainer, ''[[Village Voice]]'', November 29, 1976</ref> appearing as Darlene in the original production of [[Lanford Wilson]]'s ''Balm in Gilead'' directed by [[Marshall W. Mason|Marshall Mason]] at [[Ellen Stewart]]'s Café [[La MaMa Experimental Theatre Club|La Mama]];<ref>"Theatre: Two by Wilson" (review), by Michael Smith, ''[[Village Voice]],'' February 11, 1965</ref><ref>
''Balm in Gilead and other plays Lanford Wilson, a Spotlight Dramabook,'' by [[Lanford Wilson]], [[Hill and Wang]] (1965); ISBN (clothbound edition) 0-8090-2805-0, ISBN (hardbook edition) 0-8090-1208-1</ref> and being directed by [[Elia Kazan]] in a solo performance, for invited audiences, at the [[Actors Studio]], of which she is a member<ref>''A Method to Their Madness: The History of the [[Actors Studio]],'' by [[Foster Hirsch]], [[Da Capo Press]], 1986. {{ISBN|0-306-80268-6}}</ref> that used texts from [[Aeschylus]]' ''[[The Oresteia]]''.<ref>1959-60 [[Actors Studio]], Archives, 432 W. 44th Street, New York, New York 10036</ref>
As a playwright, her work has been presented in New York at [[La Mama Experimental Theater Club]],<ref>[http://www.lamama.org/archives/year_lists/1970page.htm "La Mama Experimental Theater Club,"] October 21, 1970</ref> the [[Manhattan Theater Club]],<ref>"Workers in Need of a Work" (review), ''[[Village Voice]],'' April 12, 1973</ref> the WPA Theater,<ref>"Metropolitan Notes," ''[[New York Times]]'', December 30, 1973</ref><ref>"The Doubts of Liberation" (review), ''[[Village Voice]]'', January 3, 1974</ref><ref>Listings, ''[[Village Voice]]'', January 24, 1974</ref><ref>"Men Steal Scene in 2 Plays for Women" (review), by [[Mel Gussow]], ''[[New York Times]]'', January 25, 1974</ref><ref>Listings, ''[[Village Voice]]'', February 7, 1974</ref><ref>"World: Women on the Rocks" (review), ''[[Saturday Review (U.S. magazine)|Saturday Review]]'' April 6, 1974</ref> The New Dramatists<ref>New Dramatists archives, 424 West 44th Street, New York, N.Y. 10036</ref> and recorded on [[WBAI]].<ref>[[WBAI]] 1970's Arts Programming initiative</ref>
She co-wrote and directed the cabaret production, ''[[Marlene Dietrich|Dietrich]]'' for the Oak Room in the [[Algonquin Hotel]],<ref>"As Melville Told Marlene, the Muse Leads the Music" (review), by [[Margo Jefferson]], ''[[New York Times]],'' September 18, 2000</ref><ref name="Bistro Bits 2000 Sep 29">"Bistro Bits," by Barbara & [[Scott Siegel]], ''Back Stage'', Vol. 41, No. 39, September 29, 2000;</ref><ref name="Time Out 2000 Jul 7">''[[Time Out (magazine)|Time Out]]'', No. 259, July 7–14, 2000</ref> which won a [[MAC Awards|MAC Award]].<ref name="Bistro Bits 2001 Apr 6">"Bistro Bits," by Barbara & [[Scott Siegel]], ''Back Stage'', Vol. 42, No. 14, April 6, 2001, pg. 13;</ref> And Ms. Petrides directed ''Tap Divas'' and the tap dance extravaganza ''Tap City'' with [[Gregory Hines]], [[Savion Glover]], [[Brenda Bufalino]] and others, which played at the [[Doris Duke]] Theater in [[Times Square]].<ref>"Terpsichore Taps to Town," by [[Jennifer Dunning]], ''[[New York Times]]'', July 6, 2001</ref><ref>"The Old Tap and the New Team Up with Affection," by [[Jennifer Dunning]], ''[[New York Times]],'' July 14, 2001</ref><ref>[http://archive.danceheritage.org/assets/7b86caea-da2e-40e1-9685-e2427bc5ca21 Dance Heritage Coalition Secure Media Network]</ref><ref>[http://archive.danceheritage.org/?facet_Choreographer%5B%5D=Bufalino%2C+Brenda&facet_Genre%5B%5D=Video Dance Heritage Coalition Secure Media Network Assets]</ref><ref>"Tap Divas" (review), ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'', July 15, 2001</ref><ref>Program printed by The New 42nd Street, Inc. in which they identified the New York City Tap Dance Festival, featuring ''Tap Divas'' and ''Tap City'' as "A Project of The New 42nd Street, Inc."</ref>
== History == The Bridge Stage of the Arts, Inc., was incorporated in New York City in 1980 as a not-for-profit organization.<ref name="Incorporation 1980"/> It was then known as The Bridge American Theater Festival, Inc. In 1995, its title was changed to The Bridge Stage of the Arts, Inc.<ref>Certificate of Amendment, filed with the Secretary of State on June 2nd 1995</ref> The Bridge works on a project by project basis.
===Festival in south of France=== ''Bridge Productions are always staged in spaces exceptional for their beauty and resonance of the past.'' Although based in Manhattan, in the 1980s, The Bridge produced summer music theater festivals in the south of France, with an emphasis on the American musical theater. Alan Jay Lerner (lyricist, librettist, [[My Fair Lady]], [[Camelot]]), [[Comden and Green]], lyricists-screenwriters [[Singin' In The Rain]], [[Will Rogers Follies]]) tap dancer [[Honi Coles]], ([[Tony Award]] winner, [[My One and Only (musical)|My One and Only]]), [[Virgil Thomson]], (critic and composer, Four Saints in Three Acts), members of the [[American Dance Machine]] and of [[Joseph Chaikin]]'s experimental [[The Open Theater]], and others performed at night and taught master classes during the day. Each summer, through the invitation of The Bridge and the International Theatre Institute,<ref>"Theatre Notes," ''International Theatre Institute USA,'' No. 107, May 1982</ref> (a branch of [[UNESCO]]), 150 actors, singers, dancers, choreographers, playwrights, composers, directors and lyricists and librettists from, at times, 22 countries including [[France]], [[China]], [[Australia]], [[Ethiopia]], [[Madagascar]], [[United States|America]] and [[Japan]] came to partake free of charge in The Bridge programs. The performances attended by an international audience were sold out.
Surrounded by sunlit vineyards and streams, the festivals' first site, in 1982, was a restored 17th century factory, in the small, medieval township of [[Saint-Chinian]], South of France, ([[Languedoc-Roussillon]] region), where the uniforms of [[Louis XIV]]'s regiments were once embroidered. In 1984, The Bridge Festival moved to the nearby walled medieval city of [[Beziers]] also in the [[Languedoc-Roussillon]] region of the [[South of France]].
To bring something as high spirited and new as the American musical into these timeless surroundings was thrilling, giving a sense of new in old, of continuity of tradition and the march of time.<ref>''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'', July 21, 1982</ref><ref>French newspaper ''[[Midi Libre]]'', July 2, 1982</ref><ref>French publication ''L'information du Spectacle'', June 1982</ref><ref>French newspaper ''[[Midi Libre]]'', June 25, 1982</ref><ref>French newspaper ''[[La Dépêche du Midi|La Depeche]]'', June 19, 1982</ref><ref>French newspaper ''[[La Marseillaise (journal)|La Marseillaise]]'' [[:fr:La Marseillaise (journal)|(fr)]] de [[Hérault|l'Herault]], July 1, 1982</ref><ref>French newspaper Liberation July 2, 1982</ref><ref>French newspaper ''[[La Marseillaise (journal)|La Marseillaise]]'' [[:fr:La Marseillaise (journal)|(fr)]] de [[Hérault|l'Herault]], June 25, 1982</ref><ref>French newspaper ''[[Midi Libre]]'', June 26, 1982</ref><ref>French newspaper ''[[La Dépêche du Midi|La Depeche]]'', July 6, 1982</ref><ref>French newspaper ''[[Le Monde]],'' June 24, 1982</ref><ref>French newspaper ''[[Le Figaro]],'' June 11, 1982</ref><ref>French newspaper ''[[Midi Libre]]'', July 17, 1984</ref><ref>French newspaper ''[[Midi Libre]]'', July 20, 1984</ref><ref>French newspaper ''[[Midi Libre]]'', July 22, 1984</ref><ref>French newspaper ''[[Midi Libre]]'', July 26, 1984</ref><ref>French newspaper ''[[Midi Libre]]'', July 27, 1984</ref><ref>French newspaper ''[[Midi Libre]]'', July 28, 1984</ref>
====Betty Comden review excerpted==== [[Betty Comden]] and her partner, [[Adolph Green]], were prolific lyricists and librettists of Broadway and film musicals including ''[[Singin' In The Rain]], [[Bells Are Ringing (musical)|Bells Are Ringing]]'', and ''[[On the Town (musical)|On the Town]].'' Comden gave The Bridge kudos in 1985.
{{quote| 'The Long Arm of the American Musical Stretches to [[Beziers]]'
… It is not unusual for American musicals to appear in [[London]] … nor is it strange that ''[[A Chorus Line]]'' is a smash in [[Budapest]], but just why were 50 assorted voices of musical workshop members belting out the song "Just in Time" one morning in July in the vaulted 11th century cloister of Sainte-Aphrodise in the relatively small town of [[Beziers]] (population 100,00) somewhere in the southwest of France!
'Just in time, I found you just in time …' was issuing from throats that had traveled from [[Norway]], [[Belgium]], [[Sweden]], [[France]], [[West Germany]], the [[Netherlands]], [[Israel]], [[Czechoslovakia]], [[Poland]], [[Madagascar]], [[Romania|Rumania]], [[New Jersey]] and several other of the United States, only because my partner [[Adolph Green]] and I were using that song we had written with [[Jule Styne]] for the show ''[[Bells Are Ringing (musical)|Bells are Ringing]]'' as an example of a certain kind of theatrical-musical moment. It pleased us to learn that most of the international group of students seemed to know, or at least know of the song. They spontaneously sang along, their voices echoing, perhaps as far as the foothills of the Pyrenees. Ah your music, your theater, she is indeed the international language, no?
…The concept of The Bridge, a yearly workshop and festival devoted to the American musical, to be located in France … was to be literally a bridge between countries and cultures to disseminate knowledge on the subject by assembling "stagères", working participants from all over the globe, and bringing over from America leading practitioners of [[musical theater]] to do the disseminating. Her dream was that some day in the future, for example, if [[Hal Prince]] wanted to experiment with Japanese [[Noh]] players, working with a Swedish lyricist, a Yugoslavian composer, and a Bessarabian choreographer, such an international collaboration would be assembled under the auspices of The Bridge. This is but a facetious example of the possibilities. Avra Petrides has a strong and sincere feeling about the need for open communication through the arts among the many diverse cultures of our all too unpeaceful world, and hopes The Bridge will help.<ref name="Dramatists Guild 1985 Spring" />}}
=== Performance-Forums === In 1996, in [[Lower Manhattan]], The Bridge initiated its ''Performance- Forums'' in the [[Art Deco]] "Cocoa" building at No.1 Wall Street. In this series, American/international theater artists collaborate with astrophysicists, sculptors, theologians, philosophers, poets, novelists, painters, musicians, choreographers, filmmakers, and others working in a variety of creative, scientific and intellectual disciplines. The aim: to better understand each other's endeavors and find new and exciting ways to combine them in stage production. The theme of the initial Performance-Forum was ''Time'' (as perceived by people in different disciplines and cultures.)
For several months prior to this event these people collaborated on a performance based on that theme: * [[Tom O'Horgan]], Theater director of the Broadway productions ''[[Hair (musical)|Hair]]'', ''[[Jesus Christ Superstar]]'', ''Lenny'', ''Inner City''; director for the [[Vienna State Opera]], [[New York City Opera]]; and co-author of ''Senator Joe'' at the [[Neil Simon Theater]] on [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]]. * [[Neil de Grasse Tyson]], Ph.D. Astrophysicist and Director of the [[Hayden Planetarium]]. * Michael Sherman, A futurist, who was advising governments and corporations on their long-range plans. He has made a comparative study of images of time in modern culture. * [[Min Tanaka]], International choreographer and [[Butoh]] dancer. * [[Tony Rothman]], Ph.D. Physicist specializing in cosmology, who has been on the Editorial Board of [[Scientific American]], and a [[Pulitzer Prize]] nominee. * Kirk Nurock, Composer/pianist, who has played with [[Phil Woods]], [[Chet Baker]], [[Dizzy Gillespie]] and [[Donald Byrd]]. His compositions and arrangements have been performed by [[Judy Collins]], [[Dizzy Gillespie]], [[Dick Hyman]], [[Bette Midler]], [[Jane Ira Bloom]], The [[Brecker Brothers]] and [[Jay Clayton (musician)|Jay Clayton]]. * Serge Gubelman, who has been playing the [[Didgeridu]] since the 70's. * R.M. Fischer, Sculptor and installation artist, whose work is in the permanent collections of the [[Museum of Modern Art]], the [[Whitney Museum of American Art]], The Cincinnati Art Museum, and the [[Dallas Museum of Art]], among others. His public installations include ''Rector Gate'' at [[Battery Park City]] and the ''Kansas City Sky Stations''. * [[Brenda Bufalino]], Tap dancer and Founder of the [[American Tap Dance Foundation]], who has performed as a soloist at [[Carnegie Hall]], [[Avery Fisher Hall]], the [[Smithsonian Institution]], the [[Kennedy Center]] and on [[PBS]]' [[Great Performances]] series; and- * [[Theo Bleckmann]], Vocalist and composer who has worked with [[Philip Glass]], [[Anthony Braxton]], [[Elliott Sharp]], [[Meredith Monk]] and Kirk Nurock.
This debut ''Performance-Forum'', given on March 28, 1996, was attended by approximately two hundred artists, scientists and philosophers, who, at its conclusion, participated in the ''Forum'', which took the form of a panel-led discussion on the evening's theme ''Time''.<ref name="Time Out 1996 Mar 27" /><ref name="World Notes 1996 Sum" /><ref>The [[WQXR-FM]] initiative, ''Action for the Arts'' featured The Bridge ''Performance - Forums'' in public service announcements made by The Bridge's Artistic Director, Avra Petrides (on [[WQXR-FM]]) and they were featured in their ''Action for the Arts'' "catalog" which detailed the work of 96 organizations</ref><ref>archival video tape of the entire event, held by The Bridge Stage of the Arts</ref>
=== Castle Clinton redux === In addition, in 1996, The Bridge re-introduced the beautiful 19th century reddish circular stone structure in Historic [[Battery Park]], [[Castle Clinton]], as a remarkable performance space, with the production, ''Hart and Hammerstein Centennial Plus One''. An evening of song, it was hosted by [[CBS]]' [[Charles Osgood]], and featured leading singers and Rob Fisher, then musical director of the [[Encores!]] series at the [[New York City Center]]. It was the first performance at [[Castle Clinton]] since the mid-1800s when, as an opera house, it was the [[Lincoln Center]] of its day, attracting impresarios like [[P.T. Barnum]] and performers like [[Jenny Lind]]. For the Hart & Hammerstein production, The Bridge brought in Broadway theater technicians who, by working into the wee hours of the night before the performance, erected a 30 inch high, spacious stage, and to guard against the possibility of rain bringing the performance to a close, covered the roof opening with a translucent white tent.<ref name="NYTs 1996 Jun 2" /><ref name="Courier Lifestyles 1996 Jun 3" /><ref>"[[Castle Clinton]] … Rising in the East," ''[[New York Magazine]],'' June 3, 1996</ref>
==== Robert Moses ''vs.'' Castle Clinton ==== In 1941, the [[New York City Department of Parks and Recreation|Park Commissioner]], [[Robert Moses]], wanted to raze [[Castle Clinton]], claiming it was essential to building a crossing from [[Battery Park|the Battery]] to [[Brooklyn]].<ref name="Caro 1974">''[[The Power Broker: Robert Moses and the Fall of New York]]'', by [[Robert Caro|Robert A. Caro]], [[Alfred A. Knopf|Knopf]] (1974); {{OCLC|834874}}</ref> Protests from historic preservationists and others brought this plan to a halt but not before the roof had been removed.
==Ongoing and in development== ''Promethea On The Rocks'', a project that combines theater, music, the visual arts, film, education and community involvement.<ref>Records, The Bridge Stage of the Arts' office at 101 West 78th Street, Suite 21, New York, New York 10024</ref>
==Support== The Bridge programs have been supported by organizations including the French Ministries of Culture (L'Association Française d'Artistique) and Foreign Affairs (Le Ministère des Relations Extérieures), the [[United States Department of State]], [[CBS]], [[United Technologies Corporation]] and the ''[[Daily News (New York)|Daily News]]'' Foundation.<ref name="Int Herald Trib 1984 Jul 25" /><ref>French Newspaper, ''[[Midi Libre]]'', July 29, 1984</ref><ref>French newspaper ''[[La Dépêche du Midi]]'', July 6, 1982</ref><ref>"Suzy," (column), ''[[New York Post]],'' January 29, 1986</ref><ref>Posters created by [[United Technologies]], advertising the Festival in Summer of1982</ref>

{{About||the Bruegel painting|The Fall of the Rebel Angels (Bruegel)|the 1981 film|The Fall of the Rebel Angels (film)}} {{Infobox Artwork | image_file=Peter Paul Rubens 063.jpg | image_size=200px | title=The Fall of the Damned | artist=[[Peter Paul Rubens]] | year=ca. 1620 | medium=[[Oil painting|Oil]] on [[canvas]] | height_metric= | width_metric= | height_imperial=112.60 | width_imperial =88.19 | metric_unit=cm | imperial_unit=in | museum =[[Alte Pinakothek]] | city = [[Munich]] }} '''''The Fall of the Damned''''', alternately known as '''''The Fall of the Rebel Angels'''''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.peterpaulrubens.org/Fall-Of-The-Rebel-Angels.html|title=Fall Of The Rebel Angels|publisher =Peterpaulrubens.org|accessdate=2010-11-17}}</ref> is a monumental religious painting by [[Peter Paul Rubens]]. It features a jumble of the bodies of the damned, hurled into abyss by [[Michael (archangel)|archangel Michael]] and accompanying angels. [[David Freedberg]] assessed this painting manner as the "most brilliant assemblages of lusciously naked flesh in [[Western art]]".<ref>Sophie Perryer, ''10 years 100 artists'', Struik, 2004</ref>
In 1959 an [[Vandalism of art|art vandal]] threw an acid on the painting. According to him, he did not directly destroy the work, but the acid "relieves one from the work of destruction".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.heyokamagazine.com/HEYOKA.3.PINOCELLI.htm|title=Destructivism|publisher =Heyoka Magazine|accessdate=2010-11-17}}</ref>
==Sketch== [[File:Rubens-fall-of-damned-sketch.jpg|thumb|left|Study for ''The Fall of the Damned'', c.1614-18]] The sketch of ''The Fall of the Damned'' was made in black and red [[chalk]]s, with a grey wash and is kept in the [[British Museum]]. It is assumed to be the work of a studio assistant, while Rubens then went over the drawing with brush and oil colour.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.britishmuseum.org/explore/highlights/highlight_objects/pd/p/peter_paul_rubens,_drawing_for.aspx|title=Peter Paul Rubens, drawing for The Fall of the Damned|publisher =British Museum|accessdate=2010-11-17}}</ref> The dramatic [[chiaroscuro]] of the human forms and clouds emphasizes the darkness into which these figures fall, far from the heaven light above.

{{About|the painting by Edward Burne-Jones|other uses|Golden Stairs (disambiguation){{!}}Golden Stairs}} {{Infobox Artwork | image_file=Edward Burne-Jones The Golden Stairs.jpg | image_size=275px | title=The Golden Stairs | artist=Edward Burne-Jones | year=1880 | medium=Oil on panel | height_metric=269.2 | width_metric=116.8 | metric_unit=cm | imperial_unit=in | city=London | museum=Tate Britain }} __NOTOC__ '''''The Golden Stairs''''' is one of the best-known paintings by the [[Pre-Raphaelite Brotherhood|Pre-Raphaelite]] artist [[Edward Burne-Jones]]. It was begun in 1876 and exhibited at the [[Grosvenor Gallery]] in 1880.<ref name="Wildman">Wildman and Christian (1998), pp. 246–249</ref><ref name="Wood">Wood (1997), pp. 88–89</ref>
Unlike many of Burne-Jones's works, ''The Golden Stairs'' is not based on a literary source. It has been called [[Symbolism (arts)|Symbolist]],<ref>Wood (1997), p. 88</ref> as it has no recognisable narrative, but rather sets a mood. It is a harmony of color in the tradition of the [[Aestheticism|Aesthetic]] works of the 1860s and 1870s, as a group of young women carrying musical instruments descend a spiraling staircase, dressed in classically inspired robes in tones of white, shading to gold and silver.<ref name="smarth">{{cite web | title =The Golden Stairs| work = | publisher =Smarthistory at Khan Academy | date = | url =http://smarthistory.khanacademy.org/burne-jones-the-golden-stairs.html | accessdate =31 December 2012 }}</ref><ref name="Wildman247">Wildman and Christian (1998), p. 247</ref> Critic [[F. G. Stephens]] wrote in ''[[The Athenaeum (British magazine)|The Athenaeum]]'' that the musicians "troop past like spirits in an enchanted dream ... whither they go, who they are, there is nothing to tell".<ref>Quoted in Wood (1997), p. 88</ref>
''The Golden Stairs'' was one of many paintings Burne-Jones sketched out in 1872 following a trip to Italy. He began work on the canvas in 1876 and finished it in great haste in April 1880, just days before the Grosvenor Gallery exhibition was to open. Stephens found in the painting echoes of the work of [[Piero della Francesca]], whose frescoes Burne-Jones had seen and copied in 1871.<ref name="Wildman247" /> The figures of the musicians were drawn from professional models, but the heads are young women of Burne-Jones's circle.<ref name="Wildman" /> Some identifications have been made as follows.
His daughter Margaret is fourth from top, holding a trumpet.<ref name=MacCarthy102>MacCarthy (2011), p. 102 (caption to colour plate VI)</ref> Edith Gellibrand, known by the stage name Edith Chester, is seventh from top, seen stooping.<ref>Marcus (1975), p. 54.</ref> [[May Morris]], daughter of [[William Morris]], is ninth from top, holding a violin. Frances Graham, later known as Lady Horner, daughter of [[William Graham (Glasgow MP)|William Graham]], is bottom left, holding cymbals.<ref name=MacCarthy102/> Standing behind her on the stairs is [[Mary Gladstone]], daughter of [[William Gladstone]].<ref>MacCarthy (2011), p. 277</ref> Others include Laura Tennant, later known as [[Laura Lyttelton]], and Mary Stuart-Wortley, later [[Ralph King-Milbanke, 2nd Earl of Lovelace|Lady Lovelace]].<ref name="Wildman" />
The painting was purchased by [[Cyril Flower, 1st Baron Battersea|Cyril Flower]] (1843–1907), later Lord Battersea, a politician and art patron, and was bequeathed by him to the [[Tate Britain|Tate Gallery]], where it remains.<ref name="Wildman" /><ref name="Wood" />
== Studies == <gallery> File:Edward Burne-Jones Study of the Head of a Girl for the Golden Stairs.jpeg|Study of the head of a girl, 1879 File:Edward Burne-Jones Study of two girls for the Golden Stairs.jpg|Study of two girls File:Edward Burne-Jones Study for the Golden Stairs.jpg|Study of a musician </gallery>
== References ==
=== Notes === {{external media | width = 210px | align = right | video1 =[http://smarthistory.khanacademy.org/burne-jones-the-golden-stairs.html Smarthistory - ''The Golden Stairs'']<ref name="smarth" />}} {{reflist}}
=== Bibliography === * {{cite book |last=MacCarthy |first=Fiona |authorlink=Fiona MacCarthy |year=2011 |title=The Last Pre-Raphaelite: Edward Burne-Jones and the Victorian Imagination |location=London |publisher=Faber and Faber |isbn=978-0-571-22861-4 }} * {{cite book |editor-last=Marcus |editor-first=Penelope |year=1975 |title=Burne-Jones: The paintings, graphic and decorative work of Sir Edward Burne-Jones 1833–98 |location=London |publisher=[[Arts Council of Great Britain]] |isbn=0-7287-0073-5 }} * {{cite book|last= Wood|first =Christopher|title=Burne-Jones|publisher=Phoenix Illustrated|year=1997|isbn=9780753807279}} * {{cite book|last1= Wildman|first1=Stephen|last2=Christian|first2=John |title=Edward Burne-Jones: Victorian Artist-Dreamer|url=http://libmma.contentdm.oclc.org/cdm/compoundobject/collection/p15324coll10/id/67586 |location=New York|publisher=[[Metropolitan Museum of Art]]|year=1998|isbn= 0-87099-859-5}}

http://www.mylifetime.com/shows/under-the-gunn }} '''''Under the Gunn''''' (also known as ''Project Runway: Under the Gunn'') is an American [[Reality television#Reality competition/game shows|reality competition]] series that premiered January 16, 2014, on [[Lifetime (TV network)|Lifetime]].{{cite web|last=Bentley|first=Jean|title=''Under the Gunn'': ''Project Runway'' alumni compete to become the new Tim Gunn|url=http://blog.zap2it.com/frominsidethebox/2013/11/under-the-gunn-project-runway-alums-compete-to-become-the-new-tim-gunn.html|work=Zap2it|accessdate=January 5, 2014|date=November 13, 2013}}{{cite press release|last=Bibel|first=Sara|title=Lifetime Orders Fashion Competition Series ''Under the Gunn''|url=http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2013/11/13/lifetime-orders-fashion-competition-series-under-the-gunn/215505/|publisher=TV by the Numbers|accessdate=January 5, 2014|date=November 13, 2013}} Production of the series began in November 2013,{{cite web|last=Gelt|first=Jessica|title=Lifetime picks up fashion show 'Under the Gunn' with Tim Gunn|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2013/nov/13/entertainment/la-et-st-tim-gunn-lifetime-fashion-show-20131113|work=Los Angeles Times|accessdate=January 5, 2014|date=November 13, 2013}} with the finale filmed on December 17, 2013.{{cite web|last=Thistlethwaite|first=Felicity|title=Project REDway: Heidi Klum goes for a colour block outfit as she appears at the final of Under The Gunn|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-2525196/Heidi-Klum-wears-red-Under-The-Gunn-finale.html|work=Daily Mail|accessdate=January 5, 2014|date=December 17, 2013}} The series was filmed at the [[Fashion Institute of Design and Merchandising]] in [[Los Angeles]].{{cite web|last=Walsten|first=Jessika|title=Lifetime Green Lights 'Under the Gunn'|url=http://www.multichannel.com/content/lifetime-green-lights-under-gunn/146673|publisher=NewBay Media, LLC|accessdate=January 5, 2014|date=November 13, 2014}} Guest judges included: [[Heidi Klum]], [[Neil Patrick Harris]], [[Macklemore]], [[Jaimie Alexander]], [[Zoey Deutch]], [[Zendaya]], [[Georgina Chapman]], [[Sarah Hyland]], Trina Turk, and Wendy Partridge.{{cite web|last=Bibel|first=Sara|title=Lifetime Announces 16 New Designers and Guest Judges for 'Under the Gunn' Premiering January 16|url=http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2014/01/09/lifetime-announces-16-new-designers-and-guest-judges-for-under-the-gunn-premiering-january-16/228056/|work=TV by the Numbers|accessdate=January 9, 2014|date=January 9, 2014}} ==Synopsis== Hosted by [[Tim Gunn]], ''Under the Gunn'' follows ''Project Runway'' alumni [[Mondo Guerra]], [[Anya Ayoung-Chee]], and [[Nick Verreos]] as they are handed the task of managing, coaching, and directing 15 designers.{{cite web|last=Goldberg|first=Lesley|title=Lifetime Orders Tim Gunn-Hosted Fashion Series|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/lifetime-orders-tim-gunn-hosted-655649|work=The Hollywood Reporter|accessdate=January 5, 2014|date=November 13, 2013}}{{cite web|last=Rice|first=Lynette|title=Lifetime to launch new Tim Gunn fashion series|url=http://insidetv.ew.com/2013/11/13/lifetime-to-launch-new-tim-gunn-fashion-series/|work=Entertainment Weekly|accessdate=January 5, 2014|date=November 13, 2013}} Designer [[Rachel Roy]], celebrity stylist Jen Rade, and ''[[Marie Claire]]'' senior fashion editor Zanna Roberts Rassi serve as the judges.{{cite web|last=Kwiatkowski|first=Elizabeth|title=Tim Gunn to star in new 'Under the Gunn' fashion competition premiering January 16 on Lifetime|url=http://www.realitytvworld.com/news/tim-gunn-star-in-new-under-gunn-fashion-competition-premiering-january-16-on-lifetime-15560.php|work=Reality TV World|accessdate=January 5, 2014|date=November 14, 2013}}{{cite web|last=Marechal|first=AJ|title=Tim Gunn Nabs His Own Fashion Competition Series On Lifetime|url=https://variety.com/2013/tv/news/tim-gunn-nabs-his-own-fashion-competition-series-on-lifetime-1200827088/|work=Variety|accessdate=January 5, 2014|date=November 13, 2013}} Within the first two episodes, Tim Gunn presents a challenge to the designers while Guerra, Chee, and Verreos analyze the skill level of the contestants and determine which four designers will be a part of their teams. In the following episodes, Gunn presents new challenges that test the mentors' ability to bring out the best in their designers as they guide them through the competition. Each team then competes in a series of challenges until one alumnus and one designer remains.{{cite web|last=Walsten|first=Jessika|title=Lifetime Greenlights 'Under the Gunn'|url=http://www.broadcastingcable.com/news/programming/lifetime-greenlights-under-gunn/125194?rssid=20100|work=Broadcasting & Cable|publisher=NewBay Media, LLC|accessdate=January 5, 2014|date=November 13, 2013}} The winning contestant received a cash prize of $100,000, a sewing and embroidery studio from [[Brother Industries]], an all-expense paid trip to [[Paris]], Blowpro styling products, a 2014 [[Lexus CT|Lexus CT 200h]], the opportunity to design a collection sold exclusively at [http://www.francescas.com francesca's], and a fashion spread in ''[[Marie Claire]]'' magazine The winner also worked closely with Benefit Cosmetics creative team to design a new uniform for the Benefit Cosmetics field team members. The winning mentor also received a 2014 Lexus CT 200h, a fashion spread in ''[[Marie Claire]]'' magazine plus a spot as guest editor for one year. ==Season 1== {| class="wikitable" style="font-size:90%; width:95%; text-align:center" |- ! (million) |- {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber = 1 |Title= Who Is Under the Gunn? |OriginalAirDate= {{Start date|2014|1|16}} |ShortSummary= In the premiere of the show, Tim Gunn introduces the three mentors to a group of 15 designers. He separates the designers into 2 groups- group one with 8 and the group two with 7. He announces that 3 designers will be eliminates, and that the second group will not be participating in the first challenge. The first group is led into the workroom and given a bag of 6 3-yard pieces of fabric that they have 6 hours to make an outfit that shows their design aesthetics. After the runway, the mentors take turns to pick out their team. Designers who are chosen by more than one mentor are given the opportunity to choose their mentor. Nick becomes disheartened when it appears that he is unpopular with the designers. '''First selection:''' Michelle '''Selecting Mentors:''' Mondo, Anya, Nick '''Selected Mentor:''' Mondo '''Second Selection:''' Shan '''Selecting Mentors:''' Anya, Nick '''Selected Mentor:''' Anya '''Third selection:''' Blake '''Selecting Mentors:''' Nick, Anya, Mondo '''Selected Mentor:''' Anya '''Fourth selection:''' Camila '''Selecting Mentors:''' Mondo, Nick '''Selected Mentor:''' Mondo '''Fifth Selection:''' Brady '''Selecting Mentors:''' Anya, Nick '''Selected Mentor:''' Anya '''Sixth Selection:''' Oscar '''Selection Mentor:''' Nick '''Selected Mentor:''' Nick (''uncontested'') This leaves Melissa and Natalia in the bottom two; the mentors bemoan the simplicity of Melissa's look, and raise doubts about Natalia's taste and time management. However, after a tearful appeal to the judges, both Nick and Mondo invite Natalia to be on their teams. Citing construction concerns, she ultimately chooses Nick, to his delight. |LineColor=483D8B |Aux1= |Aux2= |Aux3=Melissa |Viewers = }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber = 2 |Title= The Mentor Face Off |OriginalAirDate= {{Start date|2014|1|23}} |ShortSummary= The second group is given 30 seconds to pick out as much fabric as they want from drums scattered around the FIDM courtyard and given 6 hours to create a look that represents their aesthetic. Cognizant of the fact that there are fewer open positions for their group, several of the designers "up their game," creating a more competitive playing field for the mentors. '''First selection:''' Sam '''Selecting Mentors:''' Mondo, Anya, Nick '''Selected Mentor:''' Mondo '''Second Selection:''' Nicholas '''Selecting Mentors:''' Anya, Mondo, Nick '''Selected Mentor:''' Anya '''Third selection:''' Isabelle '''Selecting Mentors:''' Nick '''Selected Mentor:''' Nick (''uncontested'') '''Fourth selection:''' Asha '''Selecting Mentors:''' Mondo '''Selected Mentor:''' Mondo (''uncontested'') This leaves one spot on Nick's team open. Stephanie, Amy, and Rey plead their cases to Nick, but ultimately Nick states that his mind was already made up, and chooses Stephanie for his final mentee, leaving a disappointed Amy and a somewhat aggravated Rey to be eliminated. |LineColor=483D8B |Aux1= |Aux2= |Aux3=Amy & Rey |Viewers = }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber = 3 |Title= Red Carpet Showdown |OriginalAirDate= {{Start date|2014|1|30}} |ShortSummary= Tim takes the designers and mentors for a bus tour around hollywood to inspire the designers to come up with a red carpet look, with Zanna Roberts Rassi citing that the winning look would be worn by a celebrity in a future publication of ''Marie Claire''. As Tim analyzes the mentors, he finds himself stepping in to stop Nick from getting too hands-on with his designers. During the runway critique, Sam's outfit stands out for approaching red carpet clothing from a different direction and he is awarded the win; conversely, Camila is sent home for keeping her look too plain. |LineColor=483D8B |Aux1= |Aux2=Sam |Aux3= Camila |Viewers = 1.54{{cite web|url=http://www.thefutoncritic.com/ratings/2014/01/31/thursdays-cable-ratings-and-broadcast-finals-big-bang-theory-triumphs-over-american-idol-156312/cable_20140130/|title=Thursday Cable Ratings|date=January 31, 2014}} }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber = 4 |Title= Unconventional Vampire |OriginalAirDate= {{Start date|2014|2|6}} |ShortSummary= Sarah Hyland appears to promote the upcoming movie, Vampire Academy. She sets the designers with the task of making an outfit using vampire-related materials, which the designers have to run and collect from a in a graveyard-setting in the FIDM courtyard. Despite landing in the bottom two the previous week, Michelle is awarded the win over Asha for this challenge, while Anya is given the task of choosing between Brady and Nicholas as the losing designer. Ultimately, she decides that Nicholas has more potential, and sends Brady home. |LineColor=483D8B |Aux1=[[Zoey Deutch]] & Trina Turk |Aux2=Michelle |Aux3=Brady |Viewers = 1.33{{cite web|url=http://www.thefutoncritic.com/ratings/2014/02/07/thursdays-cable-ratings-and-broadcast-finals-winter-games-hold-off-big-bang-idol-964512/cable_20140206/|title=Thursday Cable Ratings|date=February 7, 2014}} }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber = 5 |Title= Hit the Stage |OriginalAirDate= {{Start date|2014|2|13}} |ShortSummary= The designers must create a performance look for Zendaya to wear onstage while on tour. The designers seem to struggle with this challenge, and during the runway critique, seven designs are critiqued, with only Shan and Asha landing on top, while Nick's entire group (Stephanie, Oscar, Natalia, and Isabelle) and Blake end up on the bottom. Despite an overwhelming consensus from the judges that seems to point to Isabelle's elimination, Nick figuratively throws her under the bus after being unable to successfully help her manage her time, which causes concern amongst his remaining designers. Zendaya--tasked with choosing the winning designer--clearly heavily favors Asha's design, and awards her the win. |LineColor=483D8B |Aux1=[[Zendaya]] |Aux2=Asha |Aux3=Isabelle |Viewers = 1.36{{cite web|url=http://www.thefutoncritic.com/ratings/2014/02/14/thursdays-cable-ratings-and-broadcast-finals-nbc-continues-win-streak-with-winter-games-449212/cable_20140213/|title=Thursday Cable Ratings|date=February 14, 2014}} }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber = 6 |Title= Pompeii Team Challenge |OriginalAirDate= {{Start date|2014|2|20}} |ShortSummary= The first team challenge requires the designers to create mini collections of 3 cohesive pieces, inspired by the Getty Villa and the movie, Pompeii. Nick's team has a shaky start, and seems unable to reach common ground. Oscar takes over the group in order to turn things around, and Nick's group ultimately ends up winning the challenge, with Oscar being cited as the clear winner in his group. Mondo's team is safe, while Anya's team is declared the losing team. Blake's outfit is praised by the judges, which leaves Shan and Nicholas up for elimination. Ultimately neither designer is eliminated due to their "potential." |LineColor=483D8B |Aux1=Wendy Partridge |Aux2=Oscar |Aux3=None |Viewers = 1.34{{cite web|url=http://www.thefutoncritic.com/ratings/2014/02/21/thursdays-cable-ratings-and-broadcast-finals-winter-games-deliver-another-20-million-viewers-for-nbc-655513/cable_20140220/|title=Thursday Cable Ratings|date=February 21, 2014}} }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber = 7 |Title= Steampunk Chic |OriginalAirDate= {{Start date|2014|2|27}} |ShortSummary= The designers are challenged to make avant-garde outfits inspired by steampunk, utilizing unconventional materials found at Travel Town Museum in Griffith Park, Los Angeles. Tensions run high between Anya and Nicholas because of his consecutive bad performances, whereas Shan has upped his game after his near elimination. Shan wins the challenge, and Anya is yet again given the task between sending Blake or Nicholas home. Apparently learning from her mistake the first time, she chooses Blake to stay. |LineColor=483D8B |Aux1=[[Georgina Chapman]] |Aux2=Shan |Aux3=Nicholas |Viewers = 1.29{{cite web|url=http://www.thefutoncritic.com/ratings/2014/02/28/thursdays-cable-ratings-and-broadcast-finals-big-bang-theory-claims-top-spot-in-viewers-demos-469213/cable_20140227/|title=Thursday Cable Ratings|date=February 28, 2014}} }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber = 8 |Title= It's an Unconventional Beach Party |OriginalAirDate= {{Start date|2014|3|6}} |ShortSummary= The designers enjoy a beach party in the California sun and then are challenged to use the materials from the seaside bash to create their looks. Frustrated with being safe since his initial win, Sam seems to struggle with his look, whereas Oscar has difficultly settling on a design for the challenge. Tim criticizes him for relying too much on the mentor critique to drive his design choices. After the runway, Mondo is given the responsibility of awarding the win to either Sam or Asha, ultimately choosing Sam for overcoming his frustrations with the challenge, and sticking to his design aesthetic. Sam is also awarded a bonus prize for creating the look that best matched the mood of the California beach party challenge. Even though Michelle is harshly criticized for making a cocktail waitress outfit and not utilizing enough unconventional materials, it's Stephanie who is sent home for yet again failing to deliver a compelling runway look. |LineColor=483D8B |Aux1=[[Georgina Chapman]] |Aux2=Sam |Aux3=Stephanie |Viewers = 1.38{{cite web|url=http://www.thefutoncritic.com/ratings/2014/03/07/thursdays-cable-ratings-and-broadcast-finals-big-bang-theory-millers-take-top-spots-471114/cable_20140306/|title=Thursday Cable Ratings|date=March 7, 2014}} }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber = 9 |Title= Trouble in the Lounge |OriginalAirDate= {{Start date|2014|3|13}} |ShortSummary= The designers are required to create day-to-night transition outfits for the runway, inspired by Glade 2-in-1s. Oscar wins the challenge, and Michelle is sent home. Mondo and Anya have problems with Natalia, and confront the judges about their decisions. |LineColor=483D8B |Aux1=[[Macklemore]] |Aux2=Oscar |Aux3=Michelle |Viewers = 1.50{{cite web|url=http://www.thefutoncritic.com/ratings/2014/03/14/thursdays-cable-ratings-and-broadcast-finals-big-bang-theory-continues-its-reign-for-cbs-760213/cable_20140313/|title=Thursday Cable Ratings|date=March 14, 2014}} }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber = 10 |Title= Crossing Teams |OriginalAirDate= {{Start date|2014|3|20}} |ShortSummary= The designers are placed in pairs across mentor groups to create a 3 look mini collection to be manufactured and sold at Francesca's. Shan and Oscar, Blake and Sam, and Natalia and Asha are paired up for this challenge. Asha is noticeably unhappy about the proposition of working with the unpredictable Natalia, and the two butt heads when Natalia seems to be wasting time. The mentors collaborate on their critiques, with Nick and Mondo seemingly disagreeing over the direction of the Asha/Natalia pairing. Several of the designers provide interviews saying that Natalia is faking her incessant emotional outbursts. Oscar, Shan, Sam, and Blake are in contention for the win, with both Shan and Oscar being chosen as the winner. Asha and Natalia both give tearful speeches after being asked which of them should be sent home, and though neither of them actually give a clear answer, Natalia insinuates that she wouldn't want Asha to feel as though she was being sent home for something Natalia did. Ultimately, Natalia is eliminated for her poor construction. |LineColor=483D8B |Aux1= Sei Jin Alt |Aux2= Oscar and Shan |Aux3= Natalia |Viewers = 1.47{{cite web|url=http://www.thefutoncritic.com/ratings/2014/03/21/thursdays-cable-ratings-and-broadcast-finals-scandal-greys-anatomy-lead-demo-pack-164313/cable_20140320/|title=Thursday Cable Ratings|date=March 21, 2014}} }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber = 11 |Title= The Benefit of Fashion |OriginalAirDate= {{Start date|2014|3|27}} |ShortSummary= The designers are paired with clients who have specific fashion needs, and are tasked with giving them makeovers. '''Oscar:''' Dani has to shop in the children's sections of stores due to her petite stature, and is in need of a more age appropriate wardrobe. '''Shan:''' Brittany is a single mom looking for exciting date look to break up the monotony of her day wear. '''Blake:''' Ruzena is looking to have her tomboyish image more feminized. '''Sam:''' Norah is looking for something that she can wear from the office to the bar. '''Asha:''' Erin is looking for a birthday outfit that celebrate her recent 50lb weight loss. All of the designers seemingly struggle in this challenge--Asha frets that the judges will send her home for the most minor issue after the previous week, while Sam is criticized for his poor fabric choices. Shan's client has an allergic reaction to sequins, and he has to make a dress for her in the two hours before the runway show. On the runway, Oscar is criticized for making Dani look old, whereas Sam and Blake both struggle to give their clients interesting designs. Asha is praised for making Erin glow with happiness, while Shan is credited with his think quick design, and is awarded the win and a bonus prize for his resourcefulness. |LineColor=483D8B |Aux1= Annie Ford Danielson |Aux2= Shan |Aux3= Blake |Viewers = 1.47{{cite web|url=http://www.thefutoncritic.com/ratings/2014/03/28/thursdays-cable-ratings-and-broadcast-finals-scandal-greys-anatomy-top-charts-458215/cable_20140327/|title=Thursday Cable Ratings|date=March 28, 2014}} }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber = 12 |Title= Superhero Fashion |OriginalAirDate= {{Start date|2014|4|3}} |ShortSummary= The designers are tasked with creating looks inspired by the attributes of [[Marvel Comics|Marvel]] Superheroes. Sam becomes emotional after he connects Hawkeye's story to his struggles as a young gay teen, and shares that his mother accidentally prevented him from committing suicide, which he had never told her. Despite this emotional breakthrough, he and Asha are put up for elimination, both of whom seem sad to be losing their best friend right before the finale. However, in a twist, both designers from Mondo's team are put through to the finale, to the distaste of the other designers and mentors. |LineColor=483D8B |Aux1= [[Jamie Alexander]] |Aux2= |Aux3= |Viewers = 1.44{{cite web|url=http://www.thefutoncritic.com/ratings/2014/04/04/thursdays-cable-ratings-and-broadcast-finals-big-bang-theory-returns-on-top-for-cbs-867313/cable_20140403/|title=Thursday Cable Ratings|date=April 4, 2014}} }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber = 13 |Title= Finale |OriginalAirDate= {{Start date|2014|4|10}} |ShortSummary= The designers must create their collections in three days. The winning designer and mentor are chosen. '''Sam's Collection:''' Inspired by the armor people build up to protect themselves, and how his armor crumbled during the competition. '''Asha's Collection:''' Inspired by "Coming to America" and the idea of Queen Nefertiti in Harlem. '''Oscar's Collection:" Inspiration unclear; seems to be inspired by Cuba and women giving life. Recycles past designs. '''Shan's Collection:''' Inspired by the dichotomy of hard and soft, using leather and lace. In the workroom, Nick is surprised at how directional Sam's collection is turning out, while Sam declares Asha his biggest competition. During critique, Mondo challenges both Asha and Sam to make their designs less costumey. Shan struggles to come up with a cohesive statement, and Oscar is reprimanded for repeating past looks. On the runway, Sam is lauded for his ability to create a cohesive, salable collection out of highly disparate fabric choices but criticized for not creating more of a show. Asha is told her collection is "next level" by the sitting judges, who appreciate her growth in the competition; however Neil and Heidi find it to be too costumey. Oscar is praised by the guest judges for a gorgeously made collection, but the main judges are disappointed at how many of his looks are disappointing remakes. The judges' disappointment in Shan's collection is palpable, with Jen Rade looking nearly in tears. The judges debate the criteria of who should win the challenge, and Tim has to reiterate the nature of the challenge itself. Shan is left out of the conversation while Asha, Oscar, and Sam are thrown around as potential winners. Ultimately, the decision comes down to Oscar and Sam, and the former is declared the winner of Under the Gunn. |LineColor=483D8B |Aux1= [[Heidi Klum]] & [[Neil Patrick Harris]] |Aux2= Oscar |Aux3= Sam, Asha & Shan |Viewers = 1.46{{cite web|url=http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2014/04/11/thursday-cable-ratings-vikings-pawn-stars-lead-night-greatest-event-in-tv-history-suits-more/253084/|title=Thursday Cable Ratings: 'Vikings' & 'Pawn Stars' Lead Night + 'Greatest Event in TV History', 'Suits' & More|last=Kondolojy|first=Amanda|work=TV by the Numbers|date=April 11, 2014|accessdate=April 11, 2014}} }} |} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== * {{official website|http://www.mylifetime.com/shows/under-the-gunn}} {{Project Runway}} {{Lifetime Shows}} [[Category:Project Runway]] [[Category:Project Runway (U.S. series)]] [[Category:2010s American television series]] [[Category:2014 American television series debuts]] [[Category:2014 American television series endings]] [[Category:American reality television series]] [[Category:English-language television programs]] [[Category:Fashion design]] [[Category:Lifetime (TV network) shows]] [[Category:Reality television spin-offs]] [[Category:Television series by Bunim/Murray Productions]] [[Category:Fashion-themed reality television series]] [[Category:Television series by The Weinstein Company]]

[[File:Robert Berry - Waywords and Meansigns 2015.jpg|thumb|Robert Berry's art for Waywords and Meansigns, 2015]] {{italic title}} '''''Waywords and Meansigns: Recreating Finnegans Wake [in its whole wholume]''''' is an international project setting [[James Joyce]]'s novel ''[[Finnegans Wake]]'' to music. Waywords and Meansigns has released two editions of audio, each offering an unabridged musical adaptation of Joyce's book. A [[Waywords and Meansigns Opendoor Edition|third edition]], featuring over 100 artists and performing much shorter passages of the book, debuted May 4, 2017.<ref>{{cite web|author=Waywords and Meansigns website| url=http://www.waywordsandmeansigns.com/listen/opendoor-edition |title=Opendoor Edition |date=4 May 2017}}</ref>
The project brought together a diverse array of musicians. A artist or group performed each chapter in the first two editions; artists performed shorter, page-length passages in the third edition. The musicians only requirements were that "the words be audible, unabridged and more or less in their original order". With a goal of making Joyce's famously obscure novel more accessible, all audio from the project is distributed freely online.<ref>{{cite web|author=Marta Bausells |url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/booksblog/2016/feb/02/finnegans-wake-music-james-joyce-birthday |title=Finnegans Wake: a musical reading sounds out a cryptic text |date=2 February 2016}}</ref>
==Background==
The Waywords and Meansigns project began in 2014 with a goal of setting James Joyce's Finnegans Wake to music unabridged.<ref>{{cite web|author=Waywords and Meansigns website| url=http://www.waywordsandmeansigns.com/about/waywords-and-meansigns/ |title=About Waywords and Meansigns |access-date=7 September 2017}}</ref> The first edition, which premiered in 2015, featured a different artist or musical group performing each of the book's seventeen chapters. The second edition, which premiered in 2016, also offered an unabridged version of the book, performed by a different set of artists and musicians.
A third edition, dubbed the [[Waywords and Meansigns Opendoor Edition]], premiered in 2017 with a focus on performing shorter passages rather than complete chapters.<ref>{{cite web|author=Waywords and Meansigns website| url=http://www.waywordsandmeansigns.com/about/waywords-and-meansigns/ |title=About Waywords and Meansigns |access-date=7 September 2017}}</ref> In an open edition, with contributors invited to create new recordings on an ongoing basis, the Opendoor Edition features over 100 contributors from 15 countries. Over 300 people have been involved in Wayords and Meansigns since 2014.<ref>{{cite web|author=Waywords and Meansigns website| url=http://www.waywordsandmeansigns.com/listen/opendoor-edition |title=Opendoor Edition |date=4 May 2017}}</ref>
While some passages in Waywords and Meansigns adhere to traditional song structures, much of the music is experimental. The musicians' only requirements were that "the words be audible, unabridged and more or less in their original order."<ref>{{cite web|author=Waywords and Meansigns website| url=http://www.waywordsandmeansigns.com/about/waywords-and-meansigns/ |title=About Waywords and Meansigns |access-date=7 September 2017}}</ref> All audio from the project is distributed freely online under [[Creative Commons license|Creative Commons licensing]]. Finn Fordham, a James Joyce scholar at [[Royal Holloway, University of London]] has called the project "wonderfully innovative"<ref>{{cite web|author=Marta Bausells |url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/booksblog/2016/feb/02/finnegans-wake-music-james-joyce-birthday |title=Finnegans Wake: a musical reading sounds out a cryptic text |website=The Guardian|date=2 February 2016}}</ref> and ''[[The Guardian]]'' has highlighted the project for making Joyce's famously difficult novel more accessible.<ref>{{cite web|author=Billy Mills |url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/booksblog/2015/apr/28/finnegans-wake-james-joyce-modern-interpretations |title=Finnegans Wake - the book the web was invented for |website=The Guardian |date=28 April 2015}}</ref>
Contributors to Waywords and Meansigns are a self-described collection of "musicians, artists, poets, scholars, weirdos, passionate Wake-heads, those totally ignorant of the Wake, and anyone generally adventurous."<ref>{{cite web|author=Waywords and Meansigns website| url=http://www.waywordsandmeansigns.com/contact/get-involved/ |title=Get Involved |access-date=7 September 2017}}</ref>
Waywords and Meansigns has been noted as a uniquely ambitious, and unusual, project.<ref>{{cite web|author=Alberto del Castillo |url=http://www.playgroundmag.net/cultura/books/centenar-personas-creado-audiolibros-historia_0_1951604840.html |title=Un centenar de personas ha creado uno de los audiolibros más locos de la historia|website=Playground Mag |date=7 April 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Joe Murray |url=https://radiofreemidwich.wordpress.com/2016/01/25/buttery-panes-joe-murray-on-neil-campbell-steve-gregoropoulos-no-artist-mel-bentley-010001111000/ |title=buttery panes: joe murray on neil campbell, steve gregoropoulos, no artist, mel bentley, 010001111000 |website=radio free midwich |date=25 January 2016}}</ref> Rock critic Jesse Jarnow applauded Waywords and Meansigns for their innovative use of the digital platform<ref>{{cite web|author=Jesse Jarnow |url=http://flavorwire.com/556284/alternate-routes-mozart-and-joyce-reimagined-inside-baseball-and-more |title=Alternate Routes: James Joyce, Baseball, and ’90s Film Inspire Wildly Ambitious Musical Experiments|date=19 January 2016}}</ref> and [[University College Dublin]]'s Digital Platform for Contemporary Irish Writing includes Waywords and Meansigns in their "Joyce Today" collection.<ref>{{cite web|author=Contemporary Irish Writing website| url=http://www.contemporaryirishwriting.ie/joyce-today |title=Joyce Today |access-date=7 September 2017}}</ref>
==Editions== ===First edition=== The first edition of ''Waywords and Meansigns'' premiered on May 4, 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/waywords-and-meansigns-recreating-finnegans-wake-in-its-whole-wholume-mw0002908864/releases |title=Allmusic: Waywords and Meansigns: Recreating Finnegans Wake (In Its Whole Wholume) }}</ref>
==== Track listing ====
Book I {{indent|5}}I.1 - Fall, pp. 3-29 - Mariana Lanari & Sjoerd Leijten, with Erik Bindervoet {{indent|5}}I.2 - The Humphriad I: His Agnomen and Reputation, pp. 30-47 - Robert Amos; Chelidon Frame; Alan Ó Raghallaigh {{indent|5}}I.3 - The Humphriad II: His Trial and Incarceration, pp 48-74 - Greg Nahabedian {{indent|5}}I.4 - The Humphriad III - His Demise and Resurrection, pp. 75-103 - Un monton, torero; with Charlie Driker-Ohren & Walker Storz {{indent|5}}I.5 - The Mamafesta, pp. 104-25 - Tim Carbone (of [[Railroad Earth]]) {{indent|5}}I.6 - Riddles: The Personages of the Manifesto, pp. 126-68 - Kevin Spenst {{indent|5}}I.7 - Shem the Penman, pp. 169-216 - Belorusia {{indent|5}}I.8 - Anna Livia, pp. 196-59 - Dérive
Book II {{indent|5}}II.1 - The Children's Hour, pp. 216-59 - Street Kids Named Desire; with Derek Pyle, Parker McQueeney, Zach Leavitt & Samuel Nordli {{indent|5}}II.2 - The Studies, pp. 260-308 - Liz Longo & Izzy Longo, with Leo Traversa {{indent|5}}II.3 - The Stories: Tavernry in Feast, pp. 309-82 - [[Hayden Chisholm]] {{indent|5}}II.4 - Mamalujo, pp. 383-99 - Ryan Mihaly
Book III {{indent|5}}III.1 - Shaun before the People, pp. 403-28 - Gareth Flowers (of [[International Contemporary Ensemble]]) {{indent|5}}III.2 - Jaun before St. Bride's, pp. 428-73 - Steve Fly, with William Sutton {{indent|5}}III.3 - Yawn under Inquest, pp. 474-554 - Peter Quadrino, Jake Reading & Evan James {{indent|5}}III.4 - Humphrey Chimpden Earwicker and Anna Livia Plurabelle: Their Bed of Trial, pp. 555-590 - Graziano Galati
Book IV {{indent|5}}IV.1 - Dawn: Return to the Beginning, pp. 593-628 - Mariana Lanari & Sjoerd Leijten; with Eloísa Ejarque, Grace Kyne-Lilley, & Erik Bindervoet.
===Second edition=== The second edition of ''Waywords and Meansigns'' premiered on February 2, 2016.
==== Track listing ====
Book I {{indent|5}}I.1 - The Fall, pp. 3-29 - [[Barry Smolin|Mr. Smolin]] & Double Naught Spy Car {{indent|5}}I.2 - The Humphriad I: His Agnomen and Reputation, pp. 30-47 - [[David Kahne]] {{indent|5}}I.3 - The Humphriad II: His Trial and Incarceration, the Acoustic Disturbance, pp 48-74 - Steve Gregoropoulos (of [[Lavender Diamond]]) {{indent|5}}I.4 - The Humphriad III: His Demise and Resurrection, pp. 75-103 - Rio Matchett {{indent|5}}I.5 - The Mamafesta of Anna Livia, pp. 104-25 - [[Neil Campbell (musician)|Neil Campbell]] {{indent|5}}I.6 - Riddles: The Personages of the Manifesto, pp. 126-68 - Maharadja Sweets {{indent|5}}I.7 - Shem the Penman, pp. 169-216 - [[Mike Watt]] & Adam Harvey (reportedly delayed; forthcoming in 2016) {{indent|5}}I.8 - The Washers at the Ford (aka ALP), pp. 196-59 - [[Brian Hall (author)|Brian Hall]] & [[Mary Lorson]]
Book II {{indent|5}}II.1 - The Children's Hour, pp. 216-59 - Robert Amos {{indent|5}}II.2 - The Studies: Nightlessons, pp. 260-308 - Ollie Evans, Steve Potter & Co. {{indent|5}}II.3 - The Stories: Tavernry in Feast, pp. 309-82 - Janken's Henchmæn {{indent|5}}II.4 - Bride-Ship and Gulls, pp. 383-99 - Aleorta
Book III {{indent|5}}III.1 - Shaun before the People, pp. 403-28 - SIKS {{indent|5}}III.2 - Jaun before St. Bride's, pp. 428-73 - Kio Griffith {{indent|5}}III.3 - Yawn under Inquest, pp. 474-554 - Hinson Calabrese (formerly of [[Tom Fun Orchestra]]) {{indent|5}}III.4 - Humphrey Chimpden Earwicker and Anna Livia Plurabelle: Their Bed of Trial, pp. 555-590 - Conspirators of Pleasure ([[Poulomi Desai]] and [[Simon Underwood]])
Book IV {{indent|5}}IV.1 - Ricorso, pp. 593-628 riverrunning back to The Fall, pp. 3-29 - Graziano Galati
===Third edition=== {{Main article|Waywords and Meansigns Opendoor Edition}} The [[Waywords and Meansigns Opendoor Edition]] debuted May 4, 2017. This edition emphasizes brief passages rather than complete chapters, with over a hundred contributors from 15 different countries. As an open edition, listeners are invited to record their passages for inclusion.<ref>{{cite web|author=Waywords and Meansigns website| url=http://www.waywordsandmeansigns.com/listen/opendoor-edition |title=Opendoor Edition |date=4 May 2017}}</ref>
Contributors include: [[Krzysztof Bartnicki]]; [[Martyn Bates]]; [[Gregory Betts]]; [[John Wolf Brennan]]; [[Neil Campbell (musician)|Neil Campbell]]; Tim Carbone of [[Railroad Earth]] and Lou Rogai of [[Lewis & Clarke]] as Cedar Sparks; Joe Cassidy of [[Butterfly Child]]; [[Hayden Chisholm]]; Conspirators of Pleasure ([[Poulomi Desai]] and [[Simon Underwood]]); Steve Gregoropoulos of [[Lavender Diamond]]; [[S.A. Griffin]]; [[David Hurn]] and [[Abigail Hopkins]]; 90s duo Insides; [[Kinski (band)|Kinski]]; [[Ulrich Krieger]] of [[Metal Machine Trio]]; [[Little Sparta (Band)]] with [[Sally Timms]] and Martin Billheimer; [[Seán Mac Erlaine]]; Jason Merritt ([[Whip (musician)|Whip]]), Kenneth Griffin ([[Favourite Sons]], [[Rollerskate Skinny]]), [[Jason Sebastian Russo]], and Paul Dillon ([[Mercury Rev]]); [[Phil Minton]]; [[David Moss (musician)|David Moss]] and Boris Hegenbart; Papa Sprain; [[Chris Rael]]; [[Schneider TM]]; [[Gerry Smyth]]; [[Thrum (band)|Thrum]]’s [[Monica Queen]] and Johnny Smillie as Tenement and Temple; [[Owen Tromans]]; Jon Wahl of [[Claw Hammer]]; [[Mike Watt]] and Adam Harvey; and many more.<ref>{{cite web|author=Waywords and Meansigns website| url=http://www.waywordsandmeansigns.com/listen/opendoor-edition |title=Opendoor Edition |date=4 May 2017}}</ref>
==Reception==
While many reviews of Waywords and Meansigns celebrate the project for its uniqueness and ambition, other reviewers find the project's massive scope daunting. The project has been lauded for its digital distribution platform, utilizing [[Creative Commons license|Creative Commons licensing]] to freely distribute audio.<ref>{{cite web|author=Jesse Jarnow |url=http://flavorwire.com/556284/alternate-routes-mozart-and-joyce-reimagined-inside-baseball-and-more |title=Alternate Routes: James Joyce, Baseball, and ’90s Film Inspire Wildly Ambitious Musical Experiments|date=19 January 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.openculture.com/2016/02/finnegans-wake-read-by-17-artists.html |title=Hear James Joyce’s Finnegans Wake Read Unabridged & Set to Music By 17 Different Artists |date=2 February 2016}}</ref>
Writing for ''[[The Guardian]]'', Billy Mills described ''Waywords and Meansigns'' as one of many Internet-based projects helping to make Joyce's famously obscure novel more approachable.<ref>{{cite web|author=Billy Mills |url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/booksblog/2015/apr/28/finnegans-wake-james-joyce-modern-interpretations |title=Finnegans Wake - the book the web was invented for |date=28 April 2015}}</ref> While premiering advance audio from the second edition, Bort of [[Tiny Mix Tapes]] wrote "this massive undertaking will provide an endless supply of head scratches and cheers alike to its undertakers".<ref>{{cite web|author=Bort |url=http://www.tinymixtapes.com/chocolate-grinder/premiere-waywords-and-meansigns-recreating-finnegans-wake-its-whole-wholume-excerp |title=Waywords and Meansigns: Recreating Finnegans Wake [In Its Whole Wholume] [excerpts] |date=1 February 2016}}</ref>
While reviewing [[Neil Campbell (musician)|Neil Campbell]]'s contribution in [[The Wire (magazine)|''The Wire'']], Dan Barrow spoke positively of the overall project: "As a putative adaptation of the ''Wake'', does the approach of ''Waywords and Meansigns'' work? Undoubtedly."<ref>{{cite journal |last=Barrow |first=Dan |date=February 2016 |title=Review of Neil Campbell, Waywords and Meansigns |journal=The Wire |issue=384 |pages=58–59}}</ref> The [[James Joyce Centre]] dubbed the first edition "31 hours, 8 minutes, 11 seconds worth of delightful strangeness."<ref>{{cite web|author=Emily Carson |url=http://jamesjoyce.ie/waywords-meansigns-now-available-online/ |title=Waywords & Meansigns now available online! |date=6 May 2015}}</ref>
James Joyce scholar Finn Fordham called the project "wonderfully innovative" and described the second edition as "a series of unexpected transformations of this endlessly transformative text."<ref>{{cite web|author=Marta Bausells |url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/booksblog/2016/feb/02/finnegans-wake-music-james-joyce-birthday |title=Finnegans Wake: a musical reading sounds out a cryptic text |website=The Guardian|date=2 February 2016}}</ref>
The open information site and public domain blog Open Culture featured all three editions of the project, writing of the first edition "as with all compilation albums, some tracks are better than others... It is definitely a labor of love."<ref>{{cite web|author=Ted Mills |url=http://www.openculture.com/2015/05/listen-to-james-joyces-finnegans-wake-read-aloud-set-to-music-31-hours-unabridged.html |title=Hear James Joyce’s ''Finnegans Wake'' Read Aloud & Set to Music: 31 Hours of Free Unabridged Audio |date=7 May 2015}}</ref> Open Culture wrote of the second edition: "these artists try to transcend ordinary ways of reading great literature, and clearly have lots fun in the doing".<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.openculture.com/2016/02/finnegans-wake-read-by-17-artists.html |title=Hear James Joyce’s Finnegans Wake Read Unabridged & Set to Music By 17 Different Artists |date=2 February 2016}}</ref>
Aodhán Kelly and Tom De Keyser reviewed the first edition of Waywords and Meansigns for the ''[[James Joyce Quarterly]]''. Noting that "the project has gathered considerable interest among both the artistic community and Joyce enthusiasts and reading groups",<ref>{{cite journal| author =Aodhán Kelly and Tom De Keyser| title =''Waywords and Meansigns: Recreating "Finnegans Wake" (In Its Whole Wholume)'', directed by Derek Pyle| journal = ''James Joyce Quarterly''| issue = Volume 52, Number 1 | pages = 232 }}</ref> Kelly and De Keyser wrote that "each track is... a unique and completely personal interpretation of an artist's reading of the text".<ref>{{cite journal| author =Aodhán Kelly and Tom De Keyser| title =''Waywords and Meansigns: Recreating "Finnegans Wake" (In Its Whole Wholume)'', directed by Derek Pyle| journal = ''James Joyce Quarterly''| issue = Volume 52, Number 1 | pages = 230 }}</ref> The review concludes: "While we cannot say that we enjoyed the music in all instances, the project does attempt to bring challenging literature to a broader public... add[ing] another layer of richness to the life of the book with its own musical interpretation as a new form of cultural production".<ref>{{cite journal| author =Aodhán Kelly and Tom De Keyser| title =''Waywords and Meansigns: Recreating "Finnegans Wake" (In Its Whole Wholume)'', directed by Derek Pyle| journal = ''James Joyce Quarterly''| issue = Volume 52, Number 1 | pages = 232–233 }}</ref>
''[[Paste (magazine)|Paste]]'''s Jay Horton wrote of the [[Waywords and Meansigns Opendoor Edition|third edition]]: "It’s soon enough made clear that there are as many varieties of musical renderings as there are interpretations of its prose, which sparks the likely-unavoidable problem concerning the songs and the book they’re taken from and the ideas it (barely) contains – there’s just too damn many."<ref>{{cite web|author=Jay Horton |url=https://www.pastemagazine.com/articles/2017/05/various-artists-waywords-and-meansigns---recreatin.html |title=Various Artists: Waywords and Meansigns - Recreating Finnegans Wake [in its whole wholume] Review |website=Paste|date=12 May 2017}}</ref> In her [[PopMatters]] review, Maria Schurr wrote of the third edition: "the well of inspiration springing from Joyce's words is thrillingly infinite."<ref>{{cite web|author=Maria Schurr |url=http://www.popmatters.com/post/waywords-and-meansigns-recreating-finnegans-wake-premiere/ |title=Waywords and Meansigns - Recreating Finnegans Wake (premiere) |website=PopMatters|date=5 May 2017}}</ref> Open Culture's Josh Jones deemed the third edition "one of the most appropriate responses to the novel in the 78 years since its publication."<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.openculture.com/2017/05/hear-james-joyces-finnegans-wake-set-to-music-features-100-musicians-including-pioneering-punk-bassist-mike-watt.html |title=Hear a Reading of James Joyce’s Finnegans Wake Set to Music: Features 100+ Musicians and Readers from Across the World |date=4 May 2017}}</ref>
